Below is the official lineup for the 13th Annual Fort Worth Weekly Music Awards Festival, 4-10pm, Sunday, June 28. No cover, as always, but bring some foldin' money for copies of our annual charity compilation album. Featuring new or previously unreleased tracks by select 2015 Music Awards nominees, including Son of Stan, Duell, Ryan Tharp, Toy Gun, Dead Vinyl, Blank-Men, Tornup & Berto G., Chris Watson Band, Shake the Moon, Igneous Grimm, Trai Bo, and Chingalotus, Frequencies, Vol. 6: Live in Studio costs $5 a pop, with proceeds benefiting Lena Pope, an 80-year-old Fort Worth nonprofit devoted to family counseling and early childhood education.

https://fortworthweekly.bandcamp.com/album/frequencies-vol-6

Through the sale of our annual compilation albums of select nominees' music over the past five years, we have raised nearly $8,000 for our assorted charity sponsors.

For more information, contact Weekly editor Anthony Mariani at anthony@fwweekly.com or 817-321-9717. Thanks for your time and attention.

See you Sunday.

It's here! Our annual compilation album featuring select nominees in our Music Awards. Frequencies, Vol. 6 includes new or previously unreleased tracks by Son of Stan, Duell, Blank-Men, Ryan Tharp, Trai Bo, Chris Watson Band, Dead Vinyl, and more! Proceeds from the $5-a-pop sale of the album will go toward Lena Pope, an 80-year-old Fort Worth nonprofit devoted to family counseling and early childhood education.

Soundcards of the album will first become available at 4-10pm on Sunday, June 28, as part of our 13th Annual Music Awards Festival. Quaker City Night Hawks, The Unlikely Candidates, Son of Stan, Pinkish Black, Ronnie Heart, Jake Paleschic, Squanto, Vincent Neil Emerson, Bitch Bricks, Shake the Moon, Dead Vinyl, Panic Volcanic, and The Cush (acoustic) are just some of the 48 Fort Worth bands slated to play at eight venues in the West 7th Street corridor: Lola's Saloon, Magnolia Motor Lounge, Trinity River Tap House (formerly The Pour House), The Grotto, The Robust Energy Drink Stage at Studio Eighty, Fred's Texas Cafe, Reservoir, and Poag Mahone's. Admission, as always, is free.

link_name: Photos from Fort Worth Weekly's post
status_message:
Yesterday @ Slide the City Ft Worth & PantherFest Thank you to everyone who came and celebrated-Although the slide dealt with mechanical issues earlier in the day, it was packed full of sliders and ready to go come 4 pm! For those who hung around, it was sure worth the wait! 
FORT WORTH SET A GUINNESS WORLD RECORD FOR THE LONGEST DISTANCE TRAVELED IN ONE HOUR ON SLIP N SLIDE
OUR RECORD SATURDAY: 1,456 people sliding down the 1,710-foot slide in one hour for a total of 2,541,060 feet, according to Guinness adjudicator Phillip Robertson.

Previous record was set 2014 in Memphis with 4,072 people sliding down a 33.36-foot slide in one hour for a total of 135,841 feet.

 WAY TO GO FORT WORTH FOR SETTING THE NEW RECORD!!
Fun times were had by all at Slide the City!

link_name: The Unbearable Lightness of Being White
status_message: Today, many question the very idea that white privilege exists, insisting that racism ended on some vague, never-named date in the past, and any more talk is just "playing the race card." But given the African-American men killed lately by law enforcement, columnist Ken Wheatcroft-Pardue offers his true story of a young white man's encounter with the law to show that just maybe there's something to the idea of white privilege.

link_name: Click here to support Trey's medical expenses by Joshua Fleming
status_message:
Phuss Drummer Recovery Efforts

To help raise money for Trey Alfaro, the Phuss drummer and 26-year-old single father who was seriously injured in a hit-and-run while riding his bicycle near Dallas last Friday, his band's frontman, Joshua Fleming, started a crowd-funding campaign. As of today, more than half of the $10,000 goal has been met. Alfaro was struck from behind by a white pickup truck and suffered a concussion, broken nose, broken teeth, and lacerations all over his body. His injuries are not life-threatening, but he will require an extensive amount of costly surgery. Visit gofundme.com/cudmz4.

In the 2014 Lone Star Awards, a statewide journalism contest, the Weekly cleaned up in the newspapers-under-100,000-circulation division. Along with second place for investigative reporting ("Toxic Legacy") and second place with freelancer Edward Brown for business story ("A Maze of Pain"), staff writer Eric Griffey won print journalist of the year. Staff writer Peter Gorman also had a big day, taking first place in both Investigative Reporting ("A Perilous Grid") and Business Story ("Shale Game"). Other Weekly winners include: staff writer Kristian Lin, second place for news or feature story ("Cellar Dwellers"); staff writer Jeff Prince, third place for investigative reporting ("Grabbing the Purse"); and freelancer Sarah Angle, third place for news or feature story ("From the Land of the Lost").

Congrats to all of the winners and to our crack editorial, sales, and production teams. The Weekly: You should be getting it … every day.
